questions.text: Which of the following is an apocrine gland?
questions.explanation:
Apocrine Glands

Merocrine Glands (Option B)

Holocrine Glands (Option C)
  • The secretions are released along with the apical part of the cell membrane.
  • Blebs are formed.
  • Mammary gland: Modified sweat gland.
  • E.g: Breast, Sweat gland
  • Also called eccrine glands.
  • The secretion is released by exocytosis without losing a part of the secretory cell
  • Secretions are released without the loss of the cell membrane.
  • E.g: Salivary glands, Pancreas
  • The whole cell membrane is lost.
  • Becomes the sebum.
  • Entire cell organelles break down and become secretions.
  • Peripheral cells are intact.
  • E.g: Sebaceous gland

questions.text: Match the following layer of skin with the cells present in it. 1. Stratum Corneum a) Melanocytes 2. Stratum Granulosum b) Keratin Squames 3. Stratum Spinosum c) Keratohyalin granules 4. Stratum Basale d) Langerhan cells
Which of the following statements is true about the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: GALT tissues are part of the Waldeyer ring.

options.label: B
options.text: Tonsils primarily produce secretory IgA to protect mucosal surfaces.

options.label: C
options.text: Tonsils are covered by stratified squamous epithelium that forms deep crypts.

options.label: D
options.text: Tonsils contain diffuse lymphoid tissue scattered in the lamina propria.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tonsils are covered by stratified squamous epithelium that forms deep crypts.
questions.explanation:
Mucosa Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT)

Tonsils
  • Includes diffuse lymphoid cells and organized aggregates (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches). (Option D)
  • The aggregations consist of lymphatic follicles (nodules) resembling lymph node structure, with possible germinal centers.
  • Between the nodules, diffuse lymphoid tissue, known as the parafollicular zone, is present.
  • Parts:
    • GALT: Found in the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., Peyer’s patches). (Option A)
    • BALT: Present in the bronchial tree.
    • Waldeyer Ring: Lymphoid tissue in the oropharynx.
  • Consists of T & B cells, Plasma cells and mast cells.
  • Antibody Production:
    • IgA: MALT produces IgA, which is the main antibody in mucosal areas, protects mucosal surfaces. (Option B)
    • IgG & IgM: Present in lamina propria.
    • IgE: Involved in allergic reactions.
  • Function:
    • Epithelium samples luminal antigens.
  • The palatine tonsils are part of Waldeyer's ring, along with the lingual, pharyngeal, and tubal tonsils.
  • They are covered by stratified squamous epithelium, which forms deep tonsillar crypts. (Option C)
  • Beneath the tonsil is a collagenous hemicapsule separating it from muscle.
  • The tonsillar tissue contains lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, similar to lymph nodes.
  • Bacteria and particles entering the crypts are passed to follicles, triggering immune responses.
  • Efferent lymphatics drain to deep cervical lymph nodes.
  • In the tubal tonsils, respiratory epithelium covers the surface instead of squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the spleen is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: White pulp occupies most of the spleen and contains a higher number of RBCs.

options.label: B
options.text: The red pulp parenchyma is supported by reticular fibers and contains sheathed capillaries.

options.label: C
options.text: B cells form an eccentric cylindrical sheath around a central artery, known as PALS.

options.label: D
options.text: The Perilymphoid zone contains numerous sinuses and abundant reticulin meshwork.

questions.correct_answer: B. The red pulp parenchyma is supported by reticular fibers and contains sheathed capillaries.

questions.text: In a histological image of the thymus, which cell type is not present in the medulla?
A pathologist is examining a lymph node biopsy. Which of the following correctly identifies these structures?

options.label: A
options.text: C- Capsule, E- Medulla, D- Cortex, A- Germinal centers

options.label: B
options.text: D- Capsule, E- Medulla, C- Cortex, A- Germinal centers

options.label: C
options.text: C- Capsule, A- Medulla, D- Cortex, E- Germinal centers

options.label: D
options.text: D- Capsule, A- Medulla, C- Cortex, E- Germinal centers

questions.correct_answer: C. C- Capsule, A- Medulla, D- Cortex, E- Germinal centers
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Function

Capsule

- Outer covering of the lymph node

- Consists mainly of collagen fibers

- May contain some elastic fibers and smooth muscle

Provides structural support and contains the lymph node contents

Subcapsular sinus

- Located just beneath the capsule

- Receives afferent lymph vessels

Initial site for incoming lymph filtration

Cortex

- Outer zone with densely packed lymphocytes

- Contains lymphatic follicles/nodules

- Divided into superficial (nodular) and deep (paracortex) regions

- Site of B-lymphocyte activity (superficial)

- T-lymphocyte area (deep/paracortex)

Lymphatic follicles

- Rounded areas within the cortex

- Contain germinal centers when activated

Sites of B-lymphocyte proliferation and differentiation

Germinal centers

- Lightly stained central region of activated follicles

- Contain proliferating B-lymphocytes (centroblasts and centrocytes)

- Site of B-cell proliferation and selection

- Indicates an active immune response

Medulla

- Inner, lighter staining region

- Contains medullary cords and sinuses

- Houses plasma cells and macrophages

- Site of antibody production and lymph filtration

Hilum

- Concave region where blood vessels enter/exit

- Site where efferent lymph vessel leaves

Provides vascular and lymphatic connections

questions.text: A histologist is examining three different cartilage samples. Sample A shows a homogeneous basophilic matrix with groups of chondrocytes in cell nests. Sample B contains numerous branching and anastomosing fibers forming a network. Sample C lacks perichondrium and has chondrocytes arranged in single rows or groups with numerous collagen bundles. Which of the following correctly identifies these cartilage types?

options.label: A
options.text: A - Elastic, B - Hyaline, C - Fibrocartilage

options.label: B
options.text: A - Hyaline, B - Elastic, C - Fibrocartilage

options.label: C
options.text: A - Fibrocartilage, B - Hyaline, C - Elastic

options.label: D
options.text: A - Hyaline, B - Fibrocartilage, C - Elastic

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Hyaline, B - Elastic, C - Fibrocartilage
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage

Fibrocartilage

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

questions.text: Match the following types of collagen with their primary location: 1. Found in cartilage (Hyaline and Elastic Cartilage) a. Type I collagen 2. Major component of basement membranes b. Type II collagen 3. Predominant in bowel and blood vessels c. Type III collagen 4. Primary collagen in bones, tendons, and dermis d. Type IV collagen
questions.explanation:
Types of Collagen

Locations

Type I

Skin, tendon, sclera, bone, fascia, dermis

Type II

Vitreous humor of eye, intervertebral disc, cartilage (Hyaline and Elastic Cartilage)

Type III

Skin, blood vessels, bowel

Type IV

Basement membrane

questions.text: A histologist is examining three different tissue samples. Sample A shows loosely arranged fibers with numerous cells and abundant ground substance. Sample B exhibits densely packed, parallel collagen bundles with elongated fibroblast nuclei. Sample C contains interwoven collagen fibers without a specific orientation. Which of the following correctly matches the samples to their connective tissue types?

options.label: A
options.text: A - Dense irregular, B - Loose connective, C - Dense regular

options.label: B
options.text: A - Loose connective, B - Dense regular, C - Dense irregular

options.label: C
options.text: A - Dense regular, B - Dense irregular, C - Loose connective

options.label: D
options.text: A - Loose connective, B - Dense irregular, C - Dense regular

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Loose connective, B - Dense regular, C - Dense irregular
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Loose Connective Tissue

Dense Regular Connective Tissue

Dense Irregular Connective Tissue

Fiber arrangement

Loosely arranged

Densely packed, parallel arrangement

Densely packed, interwoven without specific orientation

Cell content

Numerous fibroblasts and macrophages

Few cells, mainly fibroblasts

Few cells (fibroblasts)

Ground substance

Abundant

Less in amount

Less in amount

Main function

Bind different tissues together, allow tissue movement

Provide strength and resistance to tensile forces

Provide strength in multiple directions

Examples

Endomysium, subperiosteal tissue, lamina propria of GIT, hypodermis, mesentery

Tendons, ligaments, deep fascia, aponeuroses, central tendon of diaphragm, dura mater

Dermis, CT sheath of muscle and nerves, capsules of glands, sclera, periosteum

questions.text: A pathologist is analyzing a biopsy sample from a patient with suspected connective tissue disorder. Upon staining, she observes fibers that appear black with silver impregnation and form a delicate network throughout the tissue. Which of the following best describes these fibers?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Collagen Fibers

Reticular Fibers

Elastic Fibers

Appearance under light microscope

- Wavy bundles

- White on naked eye

- Fine & anastomose to form network

- Thin, branching fibers

- Single

Staining characteristics

- Pink with H&E

- Blue with Masson's trichrome

- Red with Van Gieson

- Brown with Silver impregnation (Option A)

- Black with silver impregnation (specific)

- PAS positive

- Not visible with H&E

- Black with Verhoeff's stain

- Purple with orcein stain

Functions

- Tensile strength

- Structural support in lymphoid organs

- Component of basement membrane

- Elasticity and resilience

Locations

Widespread (e.g., dermis, tendons, ligaments)

Lymphoid organs, liver, kidney, bone marrow

Blood vessels, skin, lungs, elastic cartilage

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly identifies the locations of Meissner's and Auerbach's plexus in the gastrointestinal tract, respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers; Mucosa

options.label: B
options.text: Submucosa; Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers

options.label: C
options.text: Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers; Muscularis propri

options.label: D
options.text: Between serosa and longitudinal muscle layer; Between the submucosa and mucosa

questions.correct_answer: B. Submucosa; Between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers

questions.text: Which two of the following statements about serous, mucinous, and mixed glands are correct? Serous glands produce a proteinaceous, enzyme-rich watery fluid, while mucinous glands secrete mucopolysaccharides that form a thick, viscous mucus. Cells of serous acini are triangular with centrally placed rounded nuclei, whereas cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases. The pancreas is an example of a mixed gland, containing both serous and mucous secreting acini. The lumen of mucous acini is typically smaller than that of serous acini.
questions.explanation:
Serous gland

Mucous gland

Mixed gland
  • The secretions of serous glands are proteinaceous in nature. Cells secrete an enzyme-rich watery fluid.
  • Cells of serous acini are triangular with a rounded nucleus. Their nuclei are centrally placed.
  • E.g. pancreas.
  • In mucous glands, the secretion contains mucopolysaccharides. Cells secrete mucus which is a thick, viscous, and jelly-like protective lubricant known as mucin.
  • Cells of mucous acini are tall with flat nuclei at their bases.
  • The lumen of these acini is larger than the serous acini
  • E. g. goblet cells, and minor salivary glands of the tongue and palate.
  • The gland contains acini that secrete both mucus and serous secretions
  • E.g. submandibular and sublingual glands.

questions.text: Which of the following histological features is characteristic of Barrett's esophagus?
questions.correct_answer: B. Columnar epithelium with intestinal metaplasia

questions.text: Which of the following structures in the human body is primarily lined by stratified squamous epithelium?
questions.explanation:
Openings on the face

Description

Ear
  • The external ear cavity is lined by Stratified squamous epithelium
  • Middle ear cavity, lined by stratified cuboidal epithelium
  • The middle ear cavity and external ear cavity are separated by the tympanic membrane.
  • This tympanic membrane has two epitheliums:
    • Inner layer: Simple cuboidal epithelium
    • Outer layer: Stratified squamous epithelium

Eye
  • The first layer of the cornea is lined by stratified squamous epithelium

Nasal cavity
  • Lined by Stratified squamous epithelium.
  • It is lined with skin
  • The nasal vestibule is lined by the skin with hair: Stratified squamous epithelium

Oral cavity
  • It is discussed in 2 parts:
    • Tongue, hard palate
    • Tonsils, epiglottis

Openings of perineum

Description

Urethra
  • It is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
  • Only the tip of the male urethra is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
  • The rest of the male urethra is mostly lined by stratified columnar epithelium.

Vagina
  • The transition from stratified squamous epithelium occurs at the cervix, where the vaginal epithelium meets the simple columnar epithelium of the endocervix at the squamocolumnar junction.

Anal canal
  • Simple columnar epithelium above the pectinate line.
  • Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium below the pectinate line.
  • Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium at the anal verge, continuous with the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes transitional epithelium?

options.label: A
options.text: It is specialized for absorption and secretion and consists of a single layer of cuboidal cells.

options.label: B
options.text: It is found in the skin and is composed of multiple layers of flat cells that provide a protective barrier.

options.label: C
options.text: It is found in the urinary bladder and ureters, consisting of multiple layers of cells that can stretch and change shape.

options.label: D
options.text: It lines the digestive tract and is characterized by a single layer of columnar cells that facilitate nutrient absorption.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is found in the urinary bladder and ureters, consisting of multiple layers of cells that can stretch and change shape.

questions.text: Which of the following locations contains pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium?
questions.explanation:
Stratified squamous epithelium

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium
  • Multiple layers of cells undergo maturation from a cuboidal basal layer to a flattened surface layer.
  • Basal cells continuously divide and migrate to the surface where they become anucleate squames.
  • It is present in the regions which need protection
  • It is of two types
    • Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium
    • Stratified squamous keratinized epithelium
  • Cilia are never present on true stratified epithelia.
  • True simple epithelium.
  • All cells rest on the basement membrane, but the nuclei are at varying levels, creating an illusion of multiple layers.
  • Cells exhibit polarity with nuclei mainly in the basal two-thirds.

Lines the oral cavity, pharynx, esophagus, anal canal, uterine cervix and vagina. (Options A, B, & D ruled out)
  • Respiratory epithelium in the respiratory tract. (Option C)
  • Cilia is present to move the mucus

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Simple squamous epithelium a) Proximal convoluted tubule 2. Simple cuboidal epithelium b) Gallbladder 3. Simple columnar epithelium c) Femoral Endothelium
questions.explanation:
Types of Simple epithelium

Description

Simple squamous epithelium
  • Pavemented epithelium
  • Flattened, irregularly shaped cells forming a continuous surface.
  • Lining surfaces of gas and fluid exchange
  • Lining pleural, pericardial, and peritoneal cavities to enable fluid exchange and reduce friction.
    • Peritoneum (mesothelium)
    • Vascular endothelium

 

Simple cuboidal epithelium
  • The cells are polygonal and nucleus is round located in the center of the cell.
  • Usually lines small ducts and tubules that have excretory, secretory or absorptive functions
    • Collecting tubules of the kidney
    • Small excretory ducts of the salivary glands and pancreas.
    • Microvilli- PCT of kidney

 

Simple columnar epithelium
  • Tall columnar cells with the nuclei being located in the middle of the cells.
  • Non-ciliated cells have secretory function whereas ciliated cells help in transport.
    • Non-ciliated- Gallbladder lining.
    • Microvilli- Small intestine
    • Surface cilia- Fallopian tube
    • Pseudostratification- Respiratory tract
    • Goblet cells- Small and large bowel
    • Stereocilia- Vas deferens

questions.text: Given below are two histological images 1 and 2, which of the following pairs accurately represents the tissues depicted?
questions.explanation:
Trachea

Urinary Bladder
  • Epithelium: Lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, goblet cells, serous cells, and basal cells (neuroendocrine and stem cells).
  • Ciliated columnar cells are more abundant in the lower trachea, while goblet and basal cells are more common in the upper trachea.
  • Lamina Propria: Loose, highly vascular connective tissue beneath the epithelium, becoming more condensed at deeper levels with fibroelastic tissue.
  • Submucosa: Contains seromucinous glands that decrease in number toward the lower trachea; serous cells stain strongly, mucous cells stain poorly with H&E.
  • Hyaline cartilage rings support the trachea, with the submucosa merging into the perichondrium or fibroelastic tissue between the rings.
  • Epithelium: Lined with transitional epithelium, which forms many folds when the bladder is in a relaxed state.
  • The bladder wall consists of three smooth muscle layers – inner longitudinal, outer circular, and outermost longitudinal, known collectively as the detrusor muscle.
  • These layers of smooth muscle and elastic fibers contract during micturition.
  • Muscularis Mucosa: Separate the lamina propria from the submucosa, but it is often incomplete and not always visible.
  • Adventitia: The outer adventitial coat contains arteries, veins, and lymphatic vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is characterized by the presence of compound tubuloalveolar mucous glands in the submucosa, and a muscular layer that transitions from skeletal to smooth muscle?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Esophagus

 
  • Has four layers: mucosa, submucosa, muscularis externa, and adventitia.
  • Lumen lined with nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Submucosa- compound tubuloalveolar mucous glands, known as esophageal glands proper, which aid in lubrication.
  • The upper third of the esophagus has predominantly skeletal muscle due to voluntary control during swallowing.
  • In the middle third, there is a gradual transition to smooth muscle, and the lower third consists entirely of smooth muscle.
  • Lacks a serous covering, except for a short section near its lower end.

Stomach (Option B ruled out)
  • The epithelium-forming glands are supported by Lamina Propria, a connective tissue.
  • It has a peritoneum called serosa, which is missing from the oesophagus.
  • Lined by Simple columnar epithelium and forms some gastric glands
  • Mucosa contains gastric pits or gastric foveolae.
  • The gastric glands contain:
    • Surface mucous cells- Bicarbonate ions
    • Mucous neck cells- mucus
    • Parietal (Oxyntic) cells- HCL & Intrinsic Factor.
    • Chief, peptic or zymogenic cells- Pepsin
    • Neuroendocrine cells- Serotonin & Gastrin hormone.

Small Intestine (Option C & D ruled out)

 
  • Small intestine has columnar epithelium, which has villi, and microvilli leading to formation of brush border epithelium.
  • The intestinal villi are lined by a simple columnar epithelium which is continuous with the crypts.
  • Plicae circulares (Valves of Kerckring) are circular folds given by the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Microvilli are finger-like projections to increase the surface area for absorption.
  • Lymphoid clusters called Peyer’s patches are characteristically found in the lamina propria of the small intestine.
  • Cells in the mucosa are:
    • Enterocytes
    • Paneth cells- defence
    • Goblet cells- Mucin
    • Neuroendocrine cells- hormones
